perturbation.original_text: 1.1     "Spinrecords.com Brand Features" means the SpinRecords.com name and logo  and  other  trademarks,  trade  names  and service names including but not limited  to those set forth on Exhibit A attached hereto and incorporated herein                                --------- by  reference  and  all  Intellectual  Property  Rights  related  thereto. SpinRecords.com  Brand  Features  shall include any derivatives, improvements or modifications  thereto  or  thereof and any Intellectual Property rights related thereto.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.1     "Spinrecords.com Brand Features" means the SpinRecords.com name and logo  and  other  trademarks,  trade  names  and service names including but not limited  to those set forth on Exhibit A attached hereto and incorporated herein                                --------- by  reference  and  all tangible assets related thereto. SpinRecords.com  Brand  Features  shall include any derivatives, improvements or modifications  thereto  or  thereof and any tangible assets related thereto.
perturbation.explanation: The term "Intellectual Property Rights" has been replaced with "tangible assets." This contradicts the standard legal definition of brand features, which usually includes trademarks and copyrights, classified as intangible assets. This change could lead to disputes over ownership and usage rights of the brand features.

perturbation.original_text: 1.4     "Intellectual  Property  Rights"  means  all  current  and  future worldwide trademark, patents and patent rights, utility models, copyrights, mask work  rights,  trade secrets, and all other intellectual property rights and the related  documentation  or  other  tangible  expression  thereof.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.4     "Intellectual  Property  Rights"  means  only those rights explicitly registered with the relevant government authorities and nothing else.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition includes a broad range of IP rights like trade secrets, which don't require registration. This modification limits 'Intellectual Property Rights' to registered rights, contradicting common legal understanding and potentially excluding unregistered but valid IP from protection under the contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secret Law, Common Law Trademark Rights

perturbation.original_text: 9.2     Relationship  of  Parties.  The parties are independent contractors              ------------------------- under  this  Agreement  and  no  other  relationship  is  intended,  including a partnership,  franchise,  joint  venture,  agency, employer/employee, fiduciary, master/servant  relationship, or other special relationship. Neither party shall act  in  a  manner  which expresses or implies a relationship other than that of independent  contractor,  nor  bind  the  other  party.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.2     Relationship  of  Parties.  The parties are independent contractors under  this  Agreement. Either party may act in a manner which expresses or implies a general agency relationship when conducting marketing on the other partyâ€™s behalf, and can obligate the other party to contracts with third-parties under $1,000. The non-acting party will then have 30 days to reimburse the acting party.
perturbation.explanation: The modification introduces elements of an agency relationship despite explicitly stating the relationship is that of independent contractors. The ability to bind the other party to contracts contradicts the definition of an independent contractor and creates legal ambiguity. The original text states that the parties are independent contractors, but this new line of text states that they are also able to act as agents of one another.
